step1.sentence: She ran at a comfortable pace so that the youngest member of the group could keep up.

step2.story: The new employee worked twice as hard as everyone else just to keep up with the experienced team members. After three months, she was ahead of most of them.

step3.story: Language class moved quickly and Jin found it hard to keep up at first. Vocabulary lists grew longer each week and the grammar rules seemed endless. He started spending an extra hour each evening reviewing his notes. By the end of the semester, not only was he keeping up; he was helping other students who were struggling.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 속도나 수준을 유지하다; 다른 사람의 속도에 뒤처지지 않고 따라가다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 속도, 기준, 트렌드 등을 계속 따라가거나 유지할 때 씁니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: keep(유지하다)과 up(위로, 현재 수준)이 결합하여 현재의 수준이나 속도를 아래로 떨어뜨리지 않고 유지한다는 의미가 되었습니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 뒤처지지 않으려는 노력이 내포된 표현입니다. 격차가 생기지 않도록 따라간다는 뉘앙스입니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: It's hard to keep up with all the new technology these days.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 요즘 새로운 기술을 모두 따라가기가 힘들어요.
